Table 2 Catalysts Conversion (%) Epoxide selectivity (%) References RGO-Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 93.2 88.4 This work CoSalen-LDH-del 79.5 60.1 [53] [Co(L)(HL)(NCS)]·ClO4 69 53.6 [54] [Co(L)(HL)(N3)]·ClO4 78 55.1 [54] Co-E10-26 100 24 [57] Co2+-NaX 44 60 [4] Co-SSZ-S-10 24 62 [55] Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2-Co 90.8 63.7 [56] Nano-Co3O4 supported on magnetic N-doped graphene as highly efficient catalyst for epoxidation of alkenes Zhifang Li a b Shujie Wu a Changlong Yang b Yuanyuan Ma c Xiaoran Fu a Ling Peng a Jingqi Guan a ⁎ Qiubin Kan a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun, 130023, China College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun 130023 China b College of Materials Science and Engineering, Qiqihar University, Qiqihar 161006, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Qiqihar University Qiqihar 161006 China c Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals of College of Heilongjiang Province, Qiqihar University, Qiqihar 161006, China Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals of College of Heilongjiang Province Qiqihar University Qiqihar 161006 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Novel core@shellstructuredmagneticnanocatalystsinvolvingN-dopedhybridizationofgraphenesheetsandcarbon-coatedFe3O4nanoparticles(RGO/Fe3O4@C-N) immobilized Co3O4 were prepared by a facile, green and efficient chemical approach and used as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for aerobic oxidation of styrene using air as oxidant without any reducing agent. RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 Exhibits 93.2% conversion of styrene and 88.4% selectivity to the styrene oxide and shows excellent recoverability without loss in activity and selectivity within successive runs. Besides, the synthesized catalyst can be easily recovered via simple magnetic separation and be reused for many times. The epoxidation of alkenes to the corresponding epoxides plays a vital role in fine chemical engineering. Magnetic nanocomposite catalyst RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 (RGO: reduced graphene oxide) involving Co3O4 nanoparticles immobilized on magnetic N-doped graphene was prepared by a hydrothermal method. N-dopants in the RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 can strengthen the interaction between Co3O4 nanoparticles and the support. RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 revealed higher catalytic reactivity (i.e. 93.2% conversion of styrene and 88.4% selectivity to styrene oxide) as compared to bulk Co3O4, and Co3O4 supported on N-free RGO/Fe3O4@C due to site-isolation, good dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles and efficiently synergistic effect between Co3O4 and the magnetic support. In addition, the catalyst displayed good recoverability by simple magnetic separation with negligible loss in activity and selectivity within several successive runs due to superparamagnetism. Keywords Graphene Fe3O4 Co3O4 Air Styrene 1 Introduction The selective epoxidation of alkenes to the corresponding epoxides is of great interest and importance due to its utility in flexible intermediates [1] and precursors for many useful chemical products such as drugs, agrochemicals, food additives, perfume materials and sweeteners [2,3]. For achieving high selectivity to epoxides, H2O2, TBHP or peracids was usually used as oxidant for the oxidation of alkenes [4–6]. Nonetheless, these oxidants are expensive, corrosive and unsafe and might create much serious pollution and lots of waste due to formation of undesirable products in the oxidation process. In recent years, environmental legislation has increasingly imposed stringent targets for permitted levels of pollutants. In order to meet the increasing demand for epoxides and satisfy environmental requirements, green and clear air was used as a very attractive and desirable oxidant for the epoxidation of alkenes. In most cases, a sacrificial co-reductant (i.e. aldehyde) or a promoter was used to obtain high yield and selectivity [7,8]. Up to now, the use of molecular oxygen without any co-reductant in epoxidation of alkenes is still a challenge. Many transition metal (e.g. Co, Cu and V) compounds are active homogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of alkenes [9–11]. However, the homogenous catalysts have some shortcomings in separation of the product, regeneration and recovery of the catalysts. The heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts on solid supports can address these issues. For instance, the immobilized Schiff base copper complex catalyst is active in the liquid phase partial oxidation of cyclohexene using aqueous H2O2 or tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant [12]. The immobilization of Co-Salen complex onto amine functionalized mesoporous KIT-6 is found to be an efficient and selective catalyst for the epoxidation of olefins [13]. Luo et al. reported the catalytic asymmetric epoxidation of olefins was catalyzed by a series of chiral salen Mn(III) immobilized onto azole onium modified zinc poly(styrene-phenylvinyl phosphonate)-phosphate (ZnPS-PVPA) using NaIO4 as an oxidant [14]. Recently, Co, Fe, Pt and Au nanoparticles (NPs) are widely used in a series of epoxidation reactions [5,15–17]. For example, Au nanoparticles were highly dispersed in the mesopore of (s)-(−)-2-pyrrolidinone-5-carboxylic acid (Py)-modified SBA-15 (Au/SBA-15-Py), which manifested superior catalytic properties in the oxidation of cyclohexene and styrene by molecular oxygen [1]. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles have received increasing attention since Co3O4 plays a significant role in many fields, such as energy storage and conversion, catalysis, gas sensing, and so on [18–22]. In particular, Co-based catalysts display excellent activity in the oxidation of alkenes [4,23]. In recent years, considerable efforts have been made to improve the catalytic performance of cobalt oxide by depositing it on carbon, ZSM-5, and SBA-15 etc [23–25]. Compared with silicate-based materials, carbon materials have lots of merits, such as good hydrothermal stability and excellent acid and alkali resistance. Therefore, the carbon materials have attracted increasing attention. In recent years, there are many reports about incorporating nitrogen into the carbon framework to enhance the surface property [26,27]. In addition, the modification of carbon by incorporating nitrogen could boost particle dispersity [28]. For example, for the N-doped mesoporous carbon, well-developed porosity and enriched heterogeneous sites has drawn great attention to support metal particles for advanced catalysis [29–31]. Graphene oxide (GO) has an ideal 2D structure and ample oxygen carrying functionalities (hydroxyl, epoxide, and carboxylic groups) on its basal planes and at its edges, [32] which could participate in a wide range of bonding interactions and hence serve as an ideal substrate for the deposition of inorganic nanoparticles [33]. Fe3O4 nanoparticles have been brought into sharp focus largely due to its low cost, eco-friendliness and magnetic properties [34–36]. Nevertheless, there is one big limitation in the practical application. that is that Fe3O4 nanoparticles are unstable in strongly acidic or oxidant solution [37]. Coating Fe3O4 nanoparticles with silica or carbon can protect them from being dissolved in acidic environment, enhancing the specific surface area and introducing functional groups on their surface [33]. Recently, coating magnetic materials with glucose is an efficient approach to generate carbon shells [38,39], which can be regarded as a kind of very promising new materials due to the higher stability in various chemical and physical environments such as acid or base media, as well as at high temperatures and pressures compared with silica shells [40]. Fan et al. [33] reported magnetic graphene-Fe3O4@carbon (GFC) hybrid with hierarchical nanostructures as an adsorbent for the removal of organic dyes with excellent reproducibility and recyclability. Herein we synthesized magnetic RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst by a solvothermal method. Furthermore, the catalytic properties in the epoxidation of styrene and cyclooctene using air as oxidizing agent were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and characterization The detailed information of materials and characterization was seen in the supporting information. 2.2 Synthetic procedures (Scheme 1) The synthesis route of Co3O4 supported on magnetic N-doped graphene (RGO/Fe3O4@C-N) is depicted in Scheme 1 and described as follows. 2.2.1 Catalyst preparation Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized by slightly modified Hummer method [41] (as shown in the supporting information). The synthesis procedures of reduced graphene oxide/Fe3O4 and reduced graphene oxide/Fe3O4@carbon (RGO/Fe3O4@C) were shown in the supporting information. The detailed information of Co3O4 supported on magnetic N-doped hybridization of reduced graphene oxide sheets (RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4) is as follows [24]: 62.5mg RGO/Fe3O4@C was dispersed in 189ml ethanol in an ultrasonic bath for 2h and 0.55g Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 15ml deionized water Then 4.0ml NH3·H2O was added to the above solution. The resulting mixture was refluxed at 80°C for 10h. Finally, the mixture was transferred into an autoclave, sealed and heated at 150°C for 3h. The sample was collected by magnetic separation, followed by washing with H2O and ethanol for three times. The synthesized sample was denoted as RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4. As a control experiment, RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 was prepared under the same condition with NaOH substitution for NH3·H2O. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic aerobic epoxidation of styrene or cyclooctene was carried out in a 50mL flask equipped with a reflux condenser and an air pump. In brief, substrate (8mmol), solvent (DMF, 25ml), and catalyst (10mg) were mixed. The mixture was heated to 100°C, and then oxidant (air, ca. 80mlmin−1) was imported. After filtering the solid, the filtrate was analyzed by a gas chromatography instrument (Shimadzu GC-8A) using FID detector to determine the conversion of substrate and the product yields. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by magnetic separation, followed by washing with copious solvent, and drying. The catalyst was then reused in the next reaction without further purification. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characteristics of catalysts The synthesized samples were analyzed by using XRD at high diffraction angle. As shown in Fig. S1, for GO, a broadening diffraction peak located at 2θ of 11.2° is assigned to the (0 0 1) reflection of graphene oxide, indicating that oxygen species were successfully inserted into the graphitic layers. For a series of RGO/Fe3O4 composites (Fig. 1 a–e), the diffraction peak located at 2θ of 11.2° disappears and a new peak located at 2θ of 25.3° is observed due to the removal of the oxygen-containing groups and recovery of the ordered structure of graphene [42]. Furthermore, for RGO/Fe3O4 (Fig. 1a), the diffraction peaks at 30.2, 35.6, 43.3, 53.6, 57.1, and 62.8° are indicative of cubic phase Fe3O4 (JCPDS no. 89-4319) [43]. For RGO/Fe3O4@C (Fig. 1b), a broad peak located at 2θ of 24.2° is observed owing to the amorphous carbon shell. For Co3O4 (Fig. 1c), the diffraction peaks located at 2θ of 18.9, 31.3, 36.8, 38.1, 44.9, 59.4 and 65.2° are assigned to (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (4 0 0), (5 1 1), and (4 4 0) reflections (JCPDS no. 42-1467) [44]. Meanwhile, for the cobalt-containing composites RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4, and RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 (Fig. 1d and e), the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 and carbon are still observed. In addition, the extremely weak peak at ca. 18.9° is considered to the high dispersity of cobalt species on RGO/Fe3O4@C support. The morphology and structure of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 and RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 were investigated with TEM and HRTEM (Fig. 2 ). The TEM image of GO is shown in Fig. S2. From Fig. 2a and b it is evident that Fe3O4 nanoparticles are evenly covered by a light layer of amorphous carbonaceous shell. Furthermore, Co3O4 with a uniform size of 4–8nm is well dispersed on RGO-Fe3O4@C. A high-resolution TEM image (Fig. 2c) shows well-resolved lattice fringes, corresponding to the Fe3O4, Co3O4 and carbon, which are consistent with the XRD results. From the TEM and HRTEM images, it can be found the Co3O4 nanoparticles are dispersed on both the RGO and the layer of amorphous carbonaceous shell. The EDX mapping results exhibit that carbon, cobalt, nitrogen and iron elements exist in RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4, indicating that Co3O4 supported on N-doped hybridization of graphene sheets and carbon-coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles has been successfully synthesized. In addition, the distribution of O, N, and Co elements is not consistent with that of Fe and C, which suggests that Co3O4 nanoparticles distribute uniformly on RGO/Fe3O4@C. Nevertheless, without addition of NH3·H2O (Fig. 2e), bigger Co3O4 nanoparticles are generated on RGO/Fe3O4@C, indicating that the introduction of NH3·H2O is crucial for reducing Co3O4 particle size and enhancing particle nucleation due to its coordination with cobalt cations. The BET surface area obtained from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms is 123m2/g and 41m2/g for RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 and RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4, respectively (Fig. S3). 3.2 Spectroscopy characterization The FT-IR spectra of all the synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . Characteristic bands at 1728, 1623, 1395, 1224 and 1056cm−1 are observed in the IR spectrum of GO (Fig. 3a), which is due to the vibration of CO, CC, OH, CO and COC, respectively [42]. Moreover, the characteristic bands of RGO/Fe3O4 at ca. 1623 and 1395cm−1 are absent. In the meantime, two new absorption bands at ca. 1569 and 583cm−1 are observed due to the skeletal vibration of the graphene sheets and FeO bond, respectively [45]. Characteristic peaks of RGO/Fe3O4@C appeared at 1707 and 1576cm−1 is ascribed to CO and CC vibrations, respectively, suggesting that glucose was successfully coated onto RGO/Fe3O4 during hydrothermal treatment [37]. Furthermore, the bands in the range of 1000–1300cm−1 are observed due to C-O stretching and OH bending vibrations, indicating the presence of a large number of residual hydroxyl groups on their surface. The spectrum of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 exhibits two new peaks at 662 and 571cm−1 due to the stretching vibration mode of MO (M is tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ and/or Co3+) and MO (M is octahedrally coordinated) [46], respectively, indicating that RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 was successfully prepared. Compared with RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4, the stretching vibration band of octahedrally coordinated Co3+ in RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 shifts from 571cm−1 to 691cm−1, indicates a decrease in the strength of the CoO bond in Co3O4 [46]. Raman spectroscopy was performed to investigate the structural changes of carbon materials during the chemical reactions (Fig. 4 ). The two strong bands at ca. 1345 and 1591cm−1 correspond to the well-defined D band and G band, respectively. G band is generally attributed to the first-order scattering of the E2g mode of sp2 carbon atoms in a 2D hexagonal lattice while D band is structural defects like the vibrations of the A1g-symmetry mode of sp3 carbon atoms in disordered amorphous carbon [45]. ID/IG (the Raman intensity ratio of D and G bands) is usually used to predict the presence of defects in the samples. The ID/IG value for GO, RGO/Fe3O4@C, RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 and RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 is estimated to be around 1.30, 1.25, 1.20 and 1.15, respectively. Compared with GO, the supported catalysts give a lower ratio of ID/IG, suggesting the increase of the in-plane sp2 domains and a comparatively low degree of defects of Co3O4 and Fe3O4 nanoparticles. 3.3 XPS studies Fig. 5 presents the XPS spectra of GO and the synthesized magnetic composites. The surface concentration of various elements detected by XPS and the bulk cobalt content detected by ICP-AES are shown in Table S1. For RGO/Fe3O4 (Fig. 5a), the sharp peaks centered at 711.4 and 725.2eV are due to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively, verifying that the magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles are effectively decorated on the thin reduced GO sheets [47]. Compared with RGO/Fe3O4, the intensities of the characteristic peak of Fe element dramatically reduced after coating with carbon layer (Fig. 5b), suggesting that RGO/Fe3O4 was wrapped by the carbon layer during the hydrothermal treatment. The C1s spectrum of GO (Fig. 5c) exhibits the presence of CC (284.3eV), C-OH (285.4eV), COC (287.4eV), and OCO (289.1eV), indicating that GO contained large numbers of functional groups on its surface. Furthermore, compared with GO, the C1s XPS spectra of the other magnetic composites catalysts (Fig. 5d and e) obviously exhibited a decreased intensity for the peaks corresponding to the functional groups because of effective deoxygenation of GO. The N1s spectrum of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 exhibits two peaks centered at 398.7 and 400.2eV, which can be assigned to the N atoms in pyridinic and pyrrolic [48]. In the Co2p XPS spectra of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 and RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 (Fig. 5 Co2p), the peaks centered at 796.6 and 780.9eV correspond to Co2p1/2 and Co2p3/2, which is in a good agreement with the Co2p peak of the Co3O4 NPs [49,50]. 3.4 Magnetization studies Magnetic measurements of the as-synthesized magnetic nanocomposites are measured at room temperature with an applied magnetic field sweeping from −4 to 4kOe, as shown in Fig. 6 . It is apparent that the magnetization hysteresis loops of the synthesized magnetic catalyst is S-like curve, suggesting that there is almost no coercivity or remaining magnetization when the external magnetic field is removed. Meanwhile, it implies that the prepared magnetic catalyst shows superparamagnetic behavior [45,51]. The saturated magnetization (Ms) of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 is 2.4 emu/g. Compared with Fe3O4 (not shown, Ms =89.6 emu/g), the synthesized magnetic nanocomposites exhibit a decrease in the value of Ms due to the decrease in the amount of magnetic component in the nanocomposites. Moreover, the synthesized magnetic nanocomposite (RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4) can be easily separated by an external magnetic force (inset in Fig. 6), which is significant in the field of catalytic reactions and the other practical applications with good separability and recyclability. 3.5 Catalytic tests The influence of the catalyst amount and reaction temperature on the catalytic properties of various catalysts is studied, as shown in Table 1 . Under the optimal reaction conditions, the catalytic behavior of various catalysts in aerobic oxidation of styrene or cyclooctene with DMF as solvent and air as an oxidant source was evaluated (Table 1). RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 shows 93.2% conversion of styrene and 88.4% selectivity to the styrene oxide after 8h in the first run. For comparison, the catalytic properties of Co3O4 supported on N-free RGO/Fe3O4@C (RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4), RGO/Fe3O4@C, pure Co3O4 and Fe3O4 are also investigated under the identical reaction conditions. RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 shows 61.0% conversion of styrene and 81.5% selectivity to the styrene oxide after 8h. In addition, Co3O4 and Fe3O4 Exhibit 83.1% and 30.1% conversion of styrene, respectively. Furthermore, RGO/Fe3O4@C displays only 1.3% conversion of styrene. It is worth noting that the RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst exhibits higher conversion of styrene and selectivity to the corresponding epoxide than RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4, RGO/Fe3O4@C, pure Co3O4 and Fe3O4. From the above TEM results, bigger Co3O4 nanoparticles are generated for RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 compared with RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4. For RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4, the mediation of NH3·H2O can enhance the electron-donor property of the carbon matrix, strengthen the interaction between Co3O4 and the RGO/Fe3O4@C support and enable generation of smaller Co3O4 nanoparticles and more active species than Co3O4 supported on N-free RGO/Fe3O4@C (RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4). These could explain the better conversion (93.2%) observed for the magnetic RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst. Recent studies also show that the incorporation of electron-accepting nitrogen atoms could enhance the electron-donor property of the carbon matrix, which may strengthen the interaction between carbon and guest molecules [24,28]. Therefore, the site-isolation, good dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles and the synergistic beneficial catalytic interaction between Co3O4 and the magnetic support are beneficial to enhance the catalytic activity. The epoxidation of cyclooctene over various catalysts was also examined under the similar conditions. RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 exhibits nearly 100% of conversion of cyclooctene and above 99% selectivity to epoxycyclooctane. It is suggested that the higher conversion of cyclooctene than styrene is due to electron density effect of the substrate [52]. The catalytic performance comparison was made between RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 and previously reported other related catalysts that contain Co for aerobic epoxidation of styrene (Table 2 ). This comparison indicates that RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 gives higher styrene conversion (93.2%) than the reported catalysts [4,53–56] except for the Co-E10-26 catalyst [57]. However, the epoxide selectivity is only 24% for the Co-E10-26 catalyst, much lower than that achieved over RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 (88.4%). The recoverability and stability of RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 are studied in the aerobic epoxidation of styrene under similar reaction conditions and the results are depicted in Table 1. It is evident from Table 1 that the RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst could be successfully recycled for four times without significant decrease in activity or selectivity. It is also worth noting that selectivity to the corresponding epoxide increase in the second run, which could possibly be due to the better synergistic effect between Co3O4 and the magnetic support after the first run. To verify the heterogeneity of these catalytic processes, a leaching test was performed. The catalyst in half of the volume was separated by magnetic separation at reaction temperature 100°C after reacting for 2h and the resulting clear solution was permitted to react for another 6h. The leaching result is shown in Fig. S4. From Fig. S4, it is evident that styrene could just be converted at a very low rate after magnetically separating RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst. The ICP analysis result exhibits almost no metal ion in the filter liquor, indicating leaching of active species into solution did not occur. Furthermore, the catalyst was separated by magnetic separation after the fourth run and then the filter liquor was also confirmed by ICP-AES. The result indicates that the supported Co3O4 catalyst is stable and leaching of active species into solution is insignificant. Therefore, the large majority of the catalysis is carried out by truly heterogeneous catalysis. 4 Conclusions A simple and effective hydrothermal method was developed to graft Co3O4 nanoparticles onto the magnetic N-doped RGO/Fe3O4@C support for aerobic oxidation of styrene with air as an oxidant source. The magnetic nanocomposite catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, FT-IR, Raman, XPS, ICP-AES and VSM, indicating that the supported Co3O4 catalysts have been successfully prepared. The magnetic RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity for aerobic oxidation of styrene than pure Co3O4 and N-free RGO/Fe3O4@C-Co3O4 under the same conditions due to site-isolation, good dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles and efficient synergistic effect between Co3O4 nanoparticles and the supports. By using a permanent magnet, the catalysts can be recovered and reused economically for aerobic oxidation of styrene with air as an oxidant source. This finding paves a promising and green route for environmental catalytic epoxidation. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21303069), Jilin province (20150520013JH), the Science Research Project of Heilongjiang province education department, China (12541861), the Science Research Project of Qiqihar University, China (135109303, 135109103) andcivic scientific and technological project of Qiqihar, China (GYGG-201405). coredata.dc:description: The epoxidation of alkenes to the corresponding epoxides plays a vital role in fine chemical engineering. Magnetic nanocomposite catalyst RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 (RGO: reduced graphene oxide) involving Co3O4 nanoparticles immobilized on magnetic N-doped graphene was prepared by a hydrothermal method. N-dopants in the RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 can strengthen the interaction between Co3O4 nanoparticles and the support. RGO/Fe3O4@C-N-Co3O4 revealed higher catalytic reactivity (i.e. 93.2% conversion of styrene and 88.4% selectivity to styrene oxide) as compared to bulk Co3O4, and Co3O4 supported on N-free RGO/Fe3O4@C due to site-isolation, good dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles and efficiently synergistic effect between Co3O4 and the magnetic support. In addition, the catalyst displayed good recoverability by simple magnetic separation with negligible loss in activity and selectivity within several successive runs due to superparamagnetism.
coredata.dc:title: Nano-Co3O4 supported on magnetic N-doped graphene as highly efficient catalyst for epoxidation of alkenes
